Capítulo 7: Confirmação por DIFTG, DIFDTG e DIFDSC de oxidações ocorridas na fase líquida em análises de amostras do estudo inicial No capítulo 4 mostraram -se resultados que não foram considerados na sua totalidade totalmente válidos, por assumir a hipótese de que os resultados não esperados eram decorrentes de oxidações de algumas amostras durante seu manuseio antes de sua análise em ar, o que foi mostrado pelas técnicas utilizadas para analisar os resultados.

No capítulo 5, pela necessidade de se ter uma avaliação quantitativa desse tipo de oxidação em fase líquida, sobretudo durante as análises em ambiente oxidante, desenvolveu -se e aplicou -se a técnica de análise termogravimétrica diferencia l para sua quantificação, mostrando -se inclusive essa técnica aplicável para avaliar misturas diesel -lubrificante, conforme mostrado no Capítulo 6. No presente capítulo, para validar as hipóteses apresentadas no capítulo 4, aplicou -se a técnica DIFTG par a as análises em ar e N 2 das amostras do estudo inicial feitas com razão de aquecimento de 10oC.min-1, inclusive aplicando -se mesma técnica diferencial para as curvas DTG e DSC obtidas.

Entretanto desta vez, subtraíram -se as curvas de análises por DTG e DSC em N 2 das realizadas em ar já apresentadas no capítulo 3, para que a diferença mostrasse diretamente em que faixas de temperatura ocorriam de fato aumentos da taxa de acumulação da massa oxidada e correspondente efeito exotérmico do processo de oxid ação em fase líquida.

Além de apresentar as massas percentuais máximas acumuladas de produtos oxidados na fase líquida em cada caso nas curvas DIFTG, foram também quantificadas as energias dos picos DSC resultantes do efeito exotérmico das reações de oxi dação.
Para também ter -se uma melhor e mais rápida comparação visual dos resultados manteve -se para todos os casos, as escalas dos eixos respectivos às Curvas DIFTG, DIFDTG e DIFDSC.

7.2 Curvas diferenciais obtidas para as misturas

Deriv. Weight (%/min) Temperature (°C)Sample: B5.0M_10C_600C_N2_22Jun15 Comment: B5.0M_10C_600C_N2_22Jun15 pan alumínioDSC-TGAFile: E:...\junho\B5.0M_10C_600C_N2_22Jun15 Operator: Prof.Jo/Maria Teresa Instrument: SDT Q600 V20.9 Build 20 Exo Up

de aquecimento de 10oC.min-1 Nota -se claramente que a oxidação em fase líquida começa desde o início da análise com retenção de produtos oxidados menos voláteis, que vai aumentando, significativamente, até 18,8% da massa inicial de B5, indicando que esta a mostra já devia estar mais oxidada quando da realização de sua análise em ar. Note -se que o efeito exotérmico é pequeno indicando provavelmente serem oxidações de componentes do óleo diesel, que conforme visto na Figura 7.1 tem menor entalpia resultante de oxidação.

Deriv. Weight (%/min) Temperature (°C)Sample: B10M_10C_600C_N2_22Jun15 Comment: B10M_10C_600C_N2_22Jun15 pan alumínioDSC-TGAFile: E:...\junho\B10M_10C_600C_N2_22Jun15.001 Operator: Prof.Jo/Maria Teresa Instrument: SDT Q600 V20.9 Build 20 Exo Up
de aquecimento de 10oC.min-1

Cabe notar pela curva DIFDTG, que logo após o ponto máximo de fomação de produtos oxidados em fase líquida estes se vo latilizam e ou se decompõem, pois os valores de DIFDTG que haviam aumentado sobretudo na 2ª fase de oxidação até esse ponto começam diminuir.

Os resultados mostrados para B10 mostram ter havido menor formação de produtos oxidados acumulados do que no cas o B5, por terem provavelmente sido volatilizados mais e que a oxidação ocorreu em duas etapas, o que se vê pela curva DIFTG e pelos dois picos DIFDTG sendo o primeiro menor e o segundo muito maior. Estes fatos indicam que a velocidade de formação dos pro dutos na segunda etapa de oxidação foi muito maior. Para o B10 o teor de biodiesel é o dobro em relação a B5, a massa oxidada acumulada passa ser a metade, e o efeito exotérmico da oxidação foi quadruplicado, então tudo indica que, nesse caso, mais comp onentes do biodiesel foram oxidados contribuindo para uma maior geração de calor por massa de amostra, conforme medido na curva DIFDSC. de aquecimento de 10oC.min-1 Também no caso de B15 há duas etapas de oxidação em fase líquida, tendo a primeira começado no início da análise, como ocorreu em todos os casos. Pela energia resultante liberada sobretudo na segunda etapa de oxidação, e tendo sido, conforme most rado na curva DIFTG, a massa máxima acumulada de produtos
oxidados pouco maior do que o caso anterior, tudo indica que maior quantidade de componentes do biodiesel participaram do processo oxidativo.

Deriv. Weight (%/min) Temperature (°C)Sample: B20M_10C_600C_N2_23Jun15 Comment: B20M_10C_600C_N2_23Jun15 pan alumínioDSC-TGAFile: E:...\junho\B20M_10C_600C_N2_23Jun15.001 Operator: Prof.Jo/Maria Teresa Instrument: SDT Q600 V20.9 Build 20 Exo Up

de aquecimento de 10oC.min-1 Como se vê no caso B20, o maior teor de biodiesel promoveu a formação de quase o dobro da massa oxidada acumulada em fase líquida em relação ao caso B15, gerando porém apenas 50% a ma is de energia. Como durante a faixa de temperatura do pico DIFDSC, sobretudo na da segunda etapa de geração de calor de oxidação, houve uma perda bem maior de massa percentual dos componentes oxidados, muito provavelmente do biodiesel da mistura, a maior demanda de energia de sua volatilização do biodiesel pode explicar a energia do pico DIFDSC resultante obsevado.
Os resultados acima mostram que as técnicas de DIFTG, DIFDTG e DIFDSC são ferramentas que quantificam os fenômenos de oxidação em fase líquid a da forma desenvolvida e aplicada.

Pelos resultados acima de DIFTG terem sido bem diferentes dos resultados de curvas DIFTG de mesmas misturas, analisadas no Capítulo 5, e com massas oxidadas acumuladas bem maiores, as hipóteses de que algumas das mist uras do
Capítulo 4 poderem ter sido parcialmente oxidadas entre análises foi confirmada, além da importância de se usar a nova metodologia de ordem de análise para evitar os problemas ocorridos.
CAPÍTULO 8 - CONCLUSÕES

Além dos cuidados em guardar as matérias -primas e as misturas desta pesquisa em geladeira, para evitar sua oxidação à temperatura ambiente durante armazenamento, as análises de uma mesma amostra a diferentes razões de aquecimento para estudos cinéticos tem de ser realizados no menor t empo de intervalo possível para evitar oxidações inevitáveis que podem ocorrer caso as análises sejam realizadas com grande diferença de intervalos de tempo. As análises térmicas realizadas à pressão atmosférica, mostraram que a estabilidade térmica do di esel é bem menor do que a do biodiesel. Em conseqüência, nessas condições, as misturas diesel/biodiesel aumentam sua estabilidade térmica e termo -oxidativa quanto maior é o teor de biodiesel . Em consequência a pressão ambiente, o atraso de ignição aument a com o aumento do teor de biodiesel na mistura, o que também foi comprovado pelas energias de ativação respectivas.

A máxima temperatura de estabilidade termo -oxidativa das amostras (misturas) óleo lubrificante e biodiesel foi determinado por Tonset,TG DT A para as amostras com biodiesel abaixo de for biodiesel 6.5%, e para Tonset, DTA para os valores acima deste.

Para os casos estudados os processos de oxidação iniciam -se na fase líquida e frações oxidadas mais leves são formadas durante o processo de oxi dação que são liberadas na medida que sua pressão de vapor é maior que a sua pressão parcial em fase gasosa.

À pressão atmosférica, conforme resultados das análise térmicas, o que aumenta a energia de ativação além do teor de biodiesel é o estado de oxid ação das misturas. Quanto maior o estado de sua oxidação, maior será a energia de ativação a um dado grau de conversão.

Modificações nos mecanismos de volatilização dos componentes da mistura e a decomposição térmica, verificadas pelas mudanças de valores das respectivas energias de ativação em função do grau de conversão, dependem do teor de biodiesel adicionado ao diesel e da interação química entre os dois tipos de combustívies, de origem fóssil e o renovável.

Nos mesmos graus de conversão, as mudança s promovidas pela ação da oxidação, em ambiente oxidativo (ar) necessitam de maiores valores de energia de ativação, do que quando aquecido em um ambiente inerte. Já a pressões de 100psi ou mais elevadas, conforme resultados de análises por PDSC, o dies el é que apresenta maior estabilidade térmica que o biodiesel, fazendo com que a pressões mais elevadas, como as que ocorrem em um motor a ciclo Diesel, quanto maior o teor de biodiesel no diesel menor é o atraso de ignição, porém esse fato não evita produ ção de resíduos carbonosos. O aumento progressivo do teor do biodiesel ao óleo diesel forma um excesso que não interage com o diesel se forma um componente não volátil, mas estável.

Há uma menor perda de massa nos estágios de volatilização da mistura em ambiente oxidativo (em ar) do que em ambiente inerte (N 2) , logo há a formação de produtos oxidados mais pesados e não voláteis na fase líquida. Quando aquecido no ar, o biodiesel, o óleo diesel e suas misturas sofrem mudanças na volatilização dos comp onentes, com ocorrência simultânea de oxidação em fase líquida, mesmo após sua autoignição.

As curvas DIFTG obtidas pela diferença entre as curvas TG em meio oxidativo e inerte das amostras permitem a análise quantitativa do conteúdo acumulado dos produtos oxidados em fase líquida, em função da temperatura de análise. Para as amostras de B15 e B20 ocorrem duas etapas devido ao maior teor de biodiesel presente.

As curvas DIFDTA obtidas pela diferença das respectivas curvas DTA em ambiente oxidativo (ar) e am biente inerte (N 2) , indicam os efeitos térmicos associados à formação dos produtos oxidados em fase líquida. As temperaturas de ignição das amostras estudadas e as temperaturas em que o fluxo de calor máximo foi desenvolvido a partir da combustão do gás liberado,
aumentam linearmente com o teor de biodiesel da mistura até 15% (em% de mistura).

Apêncide III – A: Biodiesel Presence Effect on the Thermal and Thermo -oxidative Stability of its Blends with Diesel Oil
PUBLICADO EM OUTUBRO DE 2017 - SIMEA 2017 –
Endereço eletrônico: https://www.proceedings.blucher.com.br/articledetails/biodiesel -presence -effect -on- the-thermal -and-thermo -oxidative -stability -of-its-blends -with-diesel -oil-26580
BIODIESEL PRESENCE EFFECT ON THE THERMAL AND THER MO-OXIDATIVE STABILITY OF ITS BLEND S WITH DIESEL OIL
Tatiana Fernandes de Oliveira1,2* e Jo Dweck1,2 Programa de Tecnologia de Processos Químicos e Bioquímicos, Escola de Química, Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro,219441 -909 Rio de Janeiro, RJ
2LABAT – Laboratório de Análises Térmicas, Escola de Química, Escola de Química Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro,219441 -909 Rio de Janeiro – RJ.

ABSTRACT Nowadaysin Brazil the biodiesel commercialization has to comply with Law #13.263, of March 23rd, 2016, which establishes in 7 vol%, the minimum mandatory percentage of addition to diesel oil. This law also indicates that in the future, this percent age will tend up to 20% (B20). The main objective of this research is to analyze the effects of the presence of biodiesel on the thermal and thermo -oxidative stability temperatures of its blends with diesel oil, as well as on their ignition temperatures. T his evaluation of alternative fuels for diesel engines was done using thermogravimetry (TG), derived thermogravimetry (DTG) and differential thermal analysis (DTA). The thermal stability was determined by the extrapolated onset

temperature of the TG loss ( onset temperature) in a nitrogen environment. The thermo -oxidative stability was determined in two ways: the first by the onset temperature of loss of mass in the TG curve in air and the second, by the onset of the oxidation in liquid phase given by the on set temperature of the first peak of DTA curve, from which, the auto -ignition temperature was also determined. The results indicate that the increase in biodiesel content influences directly the ignition delay of the blends, which occurs during analysis. The thermal and thermo - oxidative stability temperatures of the blends increase linearly with the added content of biodiesel indicating that heavier products are being formed by oxidation, which may cause problems in the diesel circulation and engine effici ency Keywords: blends biodiesel/diesel , thermal stability, thermoxidative stability, ignition temperature.

INTRODUCTION The present study analyzes the differences onthe thermal stability, on the oxidative behavior of the liquid phase and on the ignition temperatures of commercial samples of diesel oil and biodiesel (soybean, methyl route) and their blends in an inert environment and in air. The main objective is to evaluate the effect of biodiesel added content on those properties.

Used in combustion eng ines ignitedby compression, diesel oil is a complex mixture of paraffinic, naphthenic and aromatic hydrocarbons, containing 10 to 22 carbon atoms per molecule. It is an oil fraction slightly denser than kerosene and boils from 250 to 400ºC. Different relat ive proportions of those three classes of hydrocarbons influence the properties of the final fuel. Although compounds such as sulfur, oxygen and nitrogen are present in small quantities in diesel, they have a great influence on its properties, such as den sity, viscosity, flash point and other Due to the worldwide appeal for fuel sustainability, sources derived from renewable energy are preferred. The development of studies and researches looking for alternative sources to replace the fossil fue ls on a wide scale, it is important not only to increase the use of clean technologies but also to supply of energy demand, which increases every year. The biodiesel is into contexts combatting the causes of

global warming and climate change, helping Brazi l to maintain high levels of clean and renewable energies in its energy matrix. Nowadaysin Brazil, 45% of the produced energy and 18% of the consumed fuels are already from renewable sources [3].

Biodiesel is an alternative fuel composed of alkyl esters of long chain carboxylic acids derived from renewable sources. From the energy point of view, composition characteristics, such as freesulfur, high calorific value and biodegradability, are advantages which stimulate its use and reduce the CO 2 emission whic h cause the biodiesel consumption to be more viable and attractive[4].

Blends of biodiesel and diesel oil tend to improve the characteristics of the petroleum derivatives increasing the lubricity, important for diesel oil of lower sulfur percentage [5]. The oxidation stability of biodiesel is the main parameter to ensure its quality, which is influenced by its chemical composition and physicochemical properties. However, the unsaturation degree in its chemical structure highly influences the oxidation st ability at different levels [6]. The oxidation, from the point of view of chemical composition, can occur by organic substrates (unsaturated fatty acids), by hydrolysis and / or by reaction with oxygen [7]. The biodiesel has a chemical structure highly rea ctive, due to the presence of free radicals to generate unpaired electrons, which turn the molecule highly reactive [8]. Thus, volatile and non -volatile compounds are generated when increasing the oxidation rate, from the decomposition of formed peroxides [7]. According to Knothe et al. [6] the high biodiesel reactivity in oxidative environments is due to the presence of double bonds, fatty acids of the precursor oils, in the presence of water / air and metals. Often there is the formation of unstable hydro peroxides, which easilyreact generating secondary oxidation products,which cause operational problems and failures, affecting the engine performance [9].

It is important to note that, although the analyses were done at heating rates well below those actu ally occurring in engines during diesel compression, the order of the degree of influence of the biodiesel content on the thermal and the thermo - oxidative stabilities of respective blends is independent of the heating rate and actually increases in intensi ty, as the heating rate is increased [10]. Thus, the results

of the present study can be used to predict the influence of the biodiesel content on the ignition delay that will occur in their use in real engines, reminding that the stability temperatures in engines will be higher, the higher will be the heating rate therein.
MATERIALS AND METHODS
1.1 Materials

Commercial samples of biodiesel from soy oil and diesel oil (diesel S -10A), whichwerein agreement with ASTM, ABNT and ISO standard characterizatio n essays were used in this study . According to the supplier of these commercial samples their analyses were done following the Brazilian Resolution ANP number 45 of the 2014 [2]. The pure sample of diesel oil was called B0 and of the biodiesel,as B100. The biodiesel and diesel blends, which were prepared in the laboratory, were named as described in Table 1. All blends and raw materials were kept in a freezer to avoid oxidation during storage.
Table 1: Laboratory prepared blends Blend Diesel Oil (vol%) Biodiesel (vol%)
1.2 Methods

Thermal analysis of the pure commercial products B0 and B100 and their blends (B5, B10, B15 and B20) were performed in a simultaneous thermogravimetric (TG) and differential thermal analysis (DTA) equipment, model SDT - Q600 from TA Instruments. The samples were heated from 25ºC to 600ºC, using 5mg of mass in open aluminum crucibles at a heating rate of 10ºC.min-1.

As purge and operation gases, nitrogen and air were used, res pectively, for the analyzes in inert and oxidizing environments. The gas flow rate was 100 mL.min-1. A new aluminum crucible was always used for each analysis, supported on platinum support for equipment samples. This procedure was used to avoid that possi ble residues from a previous analysis could not interfere in the subsequent one. The data obtained by the TG and DTA curves were treated using the Universal Analysis software from TA Instruments [11], which also calculates and plots the thermogravimetry de rivative curves (DTG).
1.2.1. Thermal Stability

The thermal stability of a substance is obtained by the onset temperature (Tonset) of mass loss determined in a TG curve obtained at inert atmosphere conditions. The temperature is determined by the intersect ion of the tangents to the TG curve, passing by two points on the TG curve before and after the loss of mass. The point on TG curve after loss of mass, through which the second tangent is drawn, is the point at the temperature of the maximum of the DTG peak [11 -13].
1.2.2. Thermo -oxidative Stability

In general the thermal stability temperature, determined as above, is considered as the extrapolated initial temperature at which the volatilization of the sample compounds begins. In case the sample is an organic fuel , which is submitted to an air environment, the components may suffer oxidation, the generated vapors may or not ignite, depending on the conditions such as pressure, concentration of the released components and oxygen content in the gaseous phase. The temperature of thermo -oxidative stability of the sample can be obtained by the onset temperature (T onset,TG, oxvap ) of mass loss, wich is determined in the thermogravimetric curve (TG) at oxidizing atmosphere [11 -13,], in the same way that T onset in inert ambient was determined, when the extrapolated temperature of the beginning of mass loss of volatiles under oxidizing conditions is desired. However, Campello [14] found that in blends with biodiesel and lubricant oil, the T onset,TG, oxvap in air has not shown any correlation with the biodiesel content and with other conventional methods used toevaluate the oxidative stability of lubricant oils. On the other hand, he realized that the onset temperature of the first

peak of the air DTA curve of the above blends (T onset, DTA, ox liq ), which refers to the onset temperature of the oxidation in the liquid phase, was in a much better correlation with the biodiesel content.

Therefore, in this work, the temperature T onset, DTA, ox liq, indicated by Campello, was also determined,This temperature indicates in fact the onset temperature of the oxidation occurring in the liquid phase of each fuel or of the blends.
1.2.3. Autoignition Temperature

During dynamic thermal analys is using oxidative purge g ases, such as air or pure oxygen, when sample organic component pyrolysis or cracking occurs, as the contents of released gases and temperature in the gaseous phase increase, the condition for the autoignition of the already released gas mixture is attaine d, promoting a sudden and very high exothermic effect [15], after which, the burnout of the following released gases is maintained.

This fact can be seen in DTA or in differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) curves, which allows one to determine the blend o r fuel auto ignition temperature (T autoign ) at the thermal analysis operating conditions. Thus this temperature is the onset temerature of the corresponding combustion exothermic DTA or DSC peak, which, usually is preceded by an endothermic effect of the vaporization or cracking transformation releasing the organic gases [15] RESULTS AND DISCUSSION
2.1. Thermal Stability

Figures 1 to 6 show the TG / DTG / DTA curves for biodiesel, diesel and their blends (B5, B10, B15 and B20) in an inert environment (N 2) as well as the respective thermal stability (Tonset)temperatures .
Fig.1: TG/DTG/DTA curves of biodiesel (B100) in an inert environment (N 2) at 10ºC.min-1, with indication of respective thermal stability temperature

Fig. 2: TG/DTG/DTA curves of di esel oil (B0) in an inert environment (N 2) at 10ºC.min-1, with indication of the respective thermal stability temperature In Figures 1 and 2, from the TG / DTG / DTA curves of B100 and B0 respectively, it can be observed that the thermal stability of th e diesel oil is much lower than that of biodiesel, since it has more volatile components. This also shows that biodiesel is thermally more stable than diesel oil, because it has esters in its composition, which have much lower vapor pressure than the lig ht hydrocarbon fraction present in diesel.
Fig. 3: TG/DTG/DTA curves of B5 in an inert environment (N 2) , at 10ºC.min-1, with indication of the respective thermal stability temperature
Fig. 4: TG/DTG/DTA curves of B10 in an inert environment (N 2) , at 10ºC.min-1, with indication of the respectivethermal stability temperature
Fig. 5: TG/DTG/DTA curves of B15 in an inert environment (N 2) , at 10ºC.min-1, with indication of the respective thermal stability temperature

Fig. 6: TG/DTG/DTA curves of B20 in an inert environment (N 2) , at 10ºC.min-1, with indication of the respectivethermal stability temperature Figures 3 to 6 show that the thermal stability temperatures of the mixtures are higher than that of diesel oil (B0) showing that the percen tage increase (in volume) of biodiesel increases the thermal stability of the blend , indicating that there is a n interaction between the two fuels .

2.2. Therm o-oxidative Stability and Autoignition Temperatures In Figures 7 and 8 the TG / DTG / DTA curves of diesel and biodiesel in air are shown . the Tonset TG, ox,vap, Tonset, DTA, ox liq, thermo -oxidative stability temperature s, as well as the respective autoignition (T autoign )temperature s, which occur at highe r temperatures.

From the DTA curves, it can be observed that two exothermic peak are occurring. The first DTA peak, which occurs at lower temperatures , is due to the oxidation occurring in the liquid phase .The second DTA peak is due to combustion, which occurs at higher temperatures right after the aut oignition temperature. Figure 7 shows the DTA curve of biodiesel in air, with an endothermic region followed by an exothermic peak which onset occurs at 178ºCThese two peaks indicate that volatilization of the components is occurring first, but is follow ed by the liquid phase oxidation phenomenon. Right after auto-ignition occurs at 253ºC (T autoign ), followed by combustion of the residual organics .

Fig. 7: TG/DTG/DTA curves, B100, in air , at 10ºC.min-1, with indication of the Tonset, DTA , ox liq , Tonset TG ox vap and T autoign temperatures It should be noted that T onset, DTA of biodiesel is 178ºC, which occurs before Tonset TG ox vap , which in the case is 202ºC, , confirm ing the indication of Campello [14] that the Temperature T onset, DTA, ox li q is the mo re suitable to evaluate the thermo - oxidative stability of biodiesel.

Fig. 8: TG/DTG/DTA curves, B0, in air , at 10ºC.min-1, with indication of T onset, DTA , ox liq , Tonset TG ox vap eT autoign temperatures When analyzing B0 (pure diesel ), in Figure 8, i t can be observed that its Tonset TG ox vap , Tonset, DTA, ox liq , and T autoign temperatures are much lower than those of B100 (biodiesel), showing that for B0 its components are much more volatile and more easily oxidizable than those of the B100. This occurs because the latter consists of alkyl esters of long chain carboxylic acids that favor the ir oxidation at higher temperatures, while diesel oil is a complex mixture of paraffinic, naphthenic

and aromatic hydrocarbons, with more volatile components oxidizable at lower temperatures, [17] From Fig. 9 to 12, are shown the TG / DTG / DTA curves in air of the blends, with respective indication of their T onset TG ox vap , Tonset, DTA , ox liq and T autoign temperatures. It can be seen that , in all these blends the higher content is of diesel components, which onset temperatures maintain the same order of appearance than in the diesel sample analyzed in air.

Thus in these blends, as in diesel sample case, the thermo –oxidative stability is given by the beginning of mass loss in air ambient as well, the oxidation in liquid phase occurring at higher temperatures. However comparing the onset temperatures of mass loss in nitrogen (T onset) and in air (T onset TG ox vap) , the latter are little higher than the former, indicating that in air, some oxidation has occurred from the beginning of the analysis, which delayed the beginning of mass loss of the more volatile oxidized components.
Fig. 9: TG/DTG/DTA curves of B5 blend, in air at 10ºC.min-1, with indication of T onset , DTA , ox liq , Tonset TG ox vap and T autoign temperatures
Fig. 10: TG/DTG/DTA, B10blend , in air , at 10ºC.min-1with indication of Tonset TG ox vap , Tonset, DTA , ox liqand T autoign temperatures
Fig. 11: TG/DTG/DTA curves, B15 blend, in air , at 10ºC.min-1, with indication of Tonset TG ox vap Tonset, DTA , ox liq , and T utoign temperatures
Fig. 12: TG/DTG/DTA curves, B20 blend, in air , at 10ºC.min-1, 1with indication of Tonset TG ox vap , Tonset, DTA , ox liq and T autoign temperatures

Figure 13 compares the determined onset temperatures in inert and oxidative ambients as a function of biodiesel volumetric content. As shown, in general, the thermo -oxidative stability temperatures are higher than those of th ermal stability, what can be explained by the formation of heavier oxidized products in air.
Fig.13 : Thermal and thermo -oxidative stability temperatures of the blends as a function of biodiesel added content and respective auto -ignition temperatures

On the other hand, it is observed that the thermal and thermo -oxidative stability temperatures of the blends as well as those of their ignition points practically increase linearly as a function of the added biodiesel content to the diesel. This indicates a chemical interaction between these fuels and that greater

problems with the formation of heavier products will occur in engines as the content increases. The angular coefficients of the respective trend lines show that the greatest influence of the addi tion of biodiesel occurs with the oxidation temperature in liquid phase. This fact indicates that the higher is the biodiesel content in the diesel thehigher will be the ignition delay in diesel engines and the higher will be the possibility of residue f ormation.

CONCLUSIONS Although the thermal behavior of diesel is very different from that of biodiesel, since the former has more volatile and more easily oxidizable components than biodiesel, there is a chemical and physical interaction between them in t heir blends.
The thermal stability of the blends, obtained from TG curve data in nitrogen, increases linearly with the added biodiesel content, due to the higher thermal stability of its esters.

The thermo -oxidative stability of the blends obtained from TG curve data in air indicates that the temperatures required for volatilization of the oxidized lighter products increase linearly with the added biodiesel content, which may delay the ignition process.

The thermo -oxidative stability temperature of the blen d liquid phase obtained from the first DTA peak, indicates that the temperatures at which the heavier products form by liquid phase oxidation increase linearly with the biodiesel content added to the diesel.

The previous occurrence may lead to the format ion of heavier products, which may cause greater problems in the circulation of the blends in diesel engines. The ignition temperature increases linearly with the increase of biodiesel content in diesel, increasing the ignition delay of diesel engines, wh ich may affect engine efficiency.

Apêndice III -B: Trabalho Publica do
ANALYSIS OF THERMO -OXIDATIVE STABILITY OF LUBRICANT OIL CONTAMINATED WITH BIODIESEL
VIII SIAT –PUBLICADO EM SETEMBRO DE 2017 no BJTA
PREMIADO PELA EMPRESA TA INSTRUMENTS

ABSTRACT The higher is the biodiesel content in diesel, the greater i s its remaining fraction in the liquid state, which can migrate to the lubricant reservoir contaminating it. Many field trials using lubricants contaminated with biodiesel indicate changes in their important properties such as anti -wear and anti-rust ones. Thus, considering the thermal condition to which lubricants are submitted in engines, changes in their physical -chemical properties may occur, reducing their lubrication efficiency. The objective of this study was to analyze the thermal behavior and the t hermo -oxidative stability of biodiesel and lubricant blends, simulating differently contaminated lubricant states, by thermogravimetry (TG), derivative thermogravimetry (DTG) and differential thermal analysis (DTA). The thermo - oxidative stability temperatu res were determined by three different ways, two of which take into account the onset of the liquid phase oxidation identified by the first exothermic DTA peak, which occurs before the lubricant auto -ignition DTA peak. Activation energy determinations, at respective initial degrees of conversion, were also estimated for the various contamination levels, to better evaluate the oxidation process. The results indicate that the lubricant contaminated with biodiesel has a significant decrease in its oxidative stability compared to the non -contaminated one. In the studied case, up to 6.5% biodiesel contamination, the thermo - oxidative stability is determined by the onset temperature of the oxidized light components volatilization. For higher contamination levels, i t is determined by the onset temperature of the heavier components oxidation in liquid phase. Thus, the higher is the contamination level, the lower is the lubricant initial oxidation temperature and shorter will be its useful life in diesel engines submit ted too much higher temperatures.
Keywords: biodiesel,lubricant oil,thermal analysis, oxidation.

INTRODUCTION When using biodiesel/diesel blends, it was noticed that combustion residues contaminate the lubricant oil, affecting not only the lubricati on performance, but also the entire lubrication system of the diesel cycle engine, reducing its life time. Lubricant oils are mostly composed of basic oils obtained during petroleum refining. These oils can be differentiated through the oil source or throu gh the refining process from which they originate. The main differences of the mineral oils are based on their chemical structures, composed mostly of paraffins, naphthenes and/or aromatics, containing heteroatoms, such as sulfur, nitrogen and oxygen, that change their viscosity, which depends on the refinement degree [1]. Each type of fuel can have different effects on the engine and on the lubrication system, which may change some characteristics such as power and efficiency. However, although fossil fuel s are widely used in many areas, petroleum is not a source of renewable energy, which demands concern about the end of its reserves as well as environmental and social impact that this situation can cause. Biodiesel is an alternative fuel composed of alkyl esters of long chain carboxylic acids derived from renewable sources. From the energy point of view, some of its characteristics such as: sulfur -free, high -calorific power and biodegradability, guarantee the advantages that stimulates its use, since it ma y promote lower CO 2 emission, which turns its consumption more environmentally friend [2].

The lubrication system undergoes several influences with the presence of biodiesel and in the fuel, with different effects. The commercial vehicles, which represent the largest market for diesel cycle engines, as well as their consumers, require the use of products that do not interfere in the engine power and that have to be durable to ensure fuel economy [3].

The most important property of a lubricant is to ensure the effectiveness of the lubrication system in all moving parts of the engine in the operating circumstances, in which the motor engine must operate. Thus, there is some concern
about the possible effects of biodiesel contamination, on the friction and wea r of the engine [4].
It is possible to define a lubricant as a substance that has the ability to reduce the friction, heat and / or wear that may exist between two solid surfaces in relative motion [5].

The lubrication system consists of a reservoir, call ed a crankcase, an oil pump, an oil filter, bearings, pipes, channels, galleries and lubricant oil. The oil in the reservoir, or crankcase, is continuously pumped to the oil filter, where part of its impurities is retained, after which the lubricant oil is pumped into the various parts of the engine.

The contact of the moving metal parts must be lubricated in order to prevent excessive wear and to ensure the proper functioning of the motor. It is necessary to form an oil layer on the external surface of th e piston, rings and of the wall of the cylinders in order to prevent wear, to hold the combustion chamber gases and to minimize friction. Finally, a lubricant film should avoid contact of the metal surfaces in the bearings [6].

An important feature relate d to the quality of the lubricant oil is its resistance to degradation in service, which actually defines its useful life. This aspect is as considerable as the initial performance, since there is a risk to damage of some mechanical component [1].

The lub ricant oil may undergoes degradation process, become oxidized, and / or to be contaminated by the fuel, soot and other combustion products, or even by the cooling liquid. This action of contaminants can cause the deactivation or the exhaustion of the compo nents [7].

A representative quantity of substances produced during combustion can flow through the piston rings, contaminating the oil in the reservoir (crankcase), and cause varying effects. These combustion formed substances include carbon dioxide, nitrogen oxides, acid components and hydrocarbon residues [8].

In this study the thermal behavior of biodiesel -contaminated lubricant blends was analyzed to determine the effect of the biodiesel content on the thermo - oxidative blend stability, which was perfor med using TG, DTG and DTA. Activation energy determinations were also performed for the different contamination levels, to better evaluate the oxidation process during the initial degrees of conversion.

MATERIALS AND METHODS Materials The commercial sampl es of biodiesel obtained from soybean oil and lubricant oil analysis reports indicated that all the results of the physical -chemical tests were in accordance to the Brazilian National Oil Agency (ANP) Resolutions [9], as well as to ASTM, ABNT and ISO norma tive entities. Non -contaminated samples were named as B0 for lubricant oil, and as BD for biodiesel. Table 1 shows the composition of the laboratory prepared blends, simulating different degrees of lubricant oil contamination by biodiesel. Table 1: Labor atory prepared blend compositions
Sample Lubricant Oil / vol % Biodiesel / vol %

B2 B4 B8 Methods Thermal analysis of commercial B0 and BD products and their blends (B2, B4 and B8) were performed in simultaneous TA Instruments TG-DTA equipment, model SDT -Q600. Samples weighing 5mg were heated from 25 to 600 ° C, in open aluminum crucibles, at heating rates of 10, 15 and 20 ° C.min-1. For the analyses in oxidizing environment, synthetic air was used as furnace atmosphere controlling gas. The gas flow was 100 mL min-1. A new 80 μL alumina crucible was always used for each analysis, supported on platinum support

of the equipment. The data of the TG and DTA obtained curves were treated using the Universal Analysis software from TA Instruments [10], which also calculates and shows the derivative thermogravimetric curve (DTG).

Thermo -oxidative Stability One of the ways of determining the thermo -oxidative stability was done as proposed by Campello [15], which considers the first DTA peak onset temperature (Tonset, DTA ) in air as the one that indicates the thermo -oxidatve temperature limit, as explained in the following paragraphs.

In the TG curves of biodiesel lubricant oil blends, this author realized that the onset temperatures ( Tonset, TG DTG ) of the TG curves in air, when used to obtain the oxidative stability temperature, as done to obtain the thermal stability in N 2, they did not show a same behavior tendency, as the biodiesel content was increased, showing oscilating onset temperatures, probably due to biodiesel o xidation in liquid phase, besides the air oxidation action.

On the other hand, he demonstrated that the onset temperature of the first DTA peak (T onset, DTA ) of the blends in air, which refers to the onset of the oxidation in the liquid phase, showed a g ood correlation with the respective concentration of biodiesel, when used to determine the blend thermo -oxidative stability limit temperature.

Therefore, in this work the temperature Tonset, DTA , also was determined to verify when the oxidation process st arts in the liquid phase. It should be noted that Tonset , DTA always occurs at a temperature lower than Tonset, TG DTG , obtained in the TG curve, as will be shown in the results.

Therefore, besides determining Tonset, DTA temperature in each case, as sugges ted by Campello, to evaluate in the present lubricant oil blends, which would be the lowest thermo -oxidative stability temperature, the onset temperatures on the TG curves were also determined, but in two other different ways: Tonset,TG DTG temperature wa s determined by the crossing point of the tangents passing through a point of the TG curve before the beginning of mass loss and
trough a point of the TG curve at the temperature of the DTG peak (as is done to determine the thermal stability temperature i n N 2).

Tonset,TG DTA temperature was determined by the crossing point of a tangent passing through a TG curve point before the beginning of the mass loss and through a second point of the TG curve, this time, at the onset temperature of the first DTA peak , which is due to the oxidation occurring in liquid phase. As it will be seen, when T onset, TG DTA is lower than T onset, DTA , the first becomes the maximum oxidative stability temperature limit, indicating that the oxidation stability ends when lighter ox idized products are first released. In the opposite case, results indicate that oxidation in liquid phase occurs at a lower temperature than that when lighter oxidized products are released. In this case, T onset, DTA was considered as the maximum temper ature of the blend thermo - oxidative stability.

Activation Energy The isoconversional methods allow one to determine the activation energy of the transformations as a function of the conversion degree, and thus allow one to know if the mechanism of the tran sformations are changing with the degree of conversion of each product. At the same time the activation energy informs about the higher or lower quantity of energy demanded for the occurrence of the transformation.

The activation energy, Eα, of a transform ation at a given conversion degree can be determined by kinetic free isoconversional methods using data obtained by thermogravimetric analyzes carried out non -isothermally and with constant heating ratios (at least three), such as the one proposed by Ozawa -Flyn-Wall, which does not depend on the kinetic models of the transformations. This method was choosen in this work, because, actually two other tested isoconversional methods, have resulted in very similar activation energy data for same conversion degr ees, as well as same activation energy curve behaviors.

In order to evaluate the influence of the addition of biodiesel to the lubricant oil, in relation to the thermal behavior of the samples, the activation energy was calculated for the first degrees of conversion a) to verify the influence of the thermal behavior of the ble nds as function of the degree of conversion α and b) to predict the behavior of the blends with respect to the oxidation or ignition delay, according to Equation 1 [15]:

τ = f(e –Eα/RT / pb ), Eq.1 τ= oxidation or ignition delay, p = pressure, T = tempe rature, R = universal constant of gases, Eα = activation energy, b= kinetic coefficient Ozawa Flyn -Wall Method with Doyle Approximation In order to verify if the transformation mechanisms were the same during the heating process of the studied product s, by the analysis of the energy of activation, as a function of the conversion degree α, the isoconversional method of Ozawa -Flynn -Wall with Doyle approximation [17], was used. The original method of the two former scientists was expressed by equation 2[1 8], where the parameter C (α) is a function of α.

ln(β) = C( α) − Eα/(RT) Eq.2 where R is the universal gas constant, Eα is the activation energy at a degree of conversion equal to α and T is the absolute temperature at which a conversion degree α is indic ated in the TG curve, obtained at a heating rate equal to β. We have estimated the activation energies by using a newer expression, with the approximation of Doyle [19 -21], by applying it at three different heating
ratios, according to Equation 3, in whi ch the parameter g(α) is a function of α while A is the pre -exponencial factor.

Using Equation 3, the activation energy is estimated from the straight line obtained plotting ln ( β) versus 1 / T , where i ts angular coefficient is a given by Equation 4 and the linear coefficient is b given by Equation 5 : The isoconversional method was used with the data of thermogravimetric analyses of each sample. The heating rates ( β) used were 10, 15 and 20 ºC min-1. The conversion degrees ( α) used were 0.1 to 0.4. At each degree of conversion a straight line of ln (β) as a function of 1/T, was obtained, from which, the values of Eαwere calcula ted by Equation 4.

RESULTS AND DISCUSSION Thermo -oxidative S tability Figures 1 and 2 present TG, DTG and DTA curves in air for samples B0 (lubricant oil) and BD (biodiesel). As a typical example, Figure 3 present the curves for B4. These figures show t he Tonset,TG DTG and Tonset,TG DTA valueson respective TG curves and the Tonset,DTA values on respective DTA curves. In Figures 1 to 3 the mass loss and thermal effects phenomena are observed in the respective degrees of conversion. It is observed that the thermal stability of the lubricant oil B0 is much higher than that of the biodiesel (BD), due to the presence of more stable components. Thus, the blend thermo -oxidative stability temperatures are lower than that of B0, due to the presence of biodiesel (BD), which has a much lower thermo -oxidative stability than B0.

It is observed in Figure 1, in the case of lubricant oil that, due to the high temperature in which its components vaporize and decompose its auto -ignition occurs right after the liquid pha se oxidation DTA peak.

Fig. 3 : TG, DTG and DTA curvesof a typical example sample B4, in air,10 ºC min-1. Tonset ,TG DTG = 294.0 oC; T onset,TG DTA = 216.6 oC and T onset,DTA =220.4 oC In the case of biodiesel (Figure 2), there is no such strong auto -ignition, since a significant part of vaporized biodiesel is released at lower temperatures than the auto -ignition point, which do not burn under these conditions. However at temperatures higher than 250oC, from TG and DTG curves it can be seen that the mass loss still continues, this time, due to the burnout of heavier present components, which is characterized by some exothermic effects in the DTA curve after auto -ignition.

As shown in the typical example B4 of Figure 3, the biodiesel -lubricant blends are influenced by the interaction effects between the lubricant and the biodiesel, occurring visible auto -ignition in all blends when heated in the thermal analysis conditions used in this work.

In the case of samples B2, B 4 and B8, the mass changing rate presented a substantially different behavior than in the other blend cases, when approaching the exothermic peaks. The substances generated in these exothermic processes contribute to the increase of the mass loss rate, whi ch is evidenced in the DTA/DTG curves of Figure 3.

The difference between Tonset, TG, DTA and Tonset, TG, DTG results also from the oxidation process of the lubricant by the oxygenated components of biodiesel, which, because of this fact, accelerate the oxi dized products mass loss process of the blend. It is observed that the DTG curve is influenced in the temperature range of exothermic peaks of the DTA curve, changing its tendency. The higher is the energy generated in the transformations, the higher is it s contribution in the energy necessary for the volatilization of the components that generate the mass loss. From Figure 2, the DTA curve of BD (biodiesel) does not show a significant typical self -ignition peak , because the loss mass due to the volatiliza tion of its components at lower temperatures than in the blends, at which the evolved gases do not ignite. However, the DTA curve revealed the occurrence of exothermic phenomena with correspondent DTA peaks, which intensifies in the same temperature region of the ascending part of the DTG curve, indicating the occurrence of oxidation in the liquid phase simultaneously to the loss of volatile components .

Figure 4 shows the curves that correlate the different estimated oxidative stability temperatures ( Tonset, DTA, Tonset, TG, DTA and Tonset, TG, DTG ), as a function of to the content of contamination of the lubricant oil with biodiesel, according to Table 2 data.

From Figure 4 it is noticed that the Tonset, TG, DTG values as a function of the biodiesel concentration are the highest ones, and therefore, they have no physical significance as being representative of the thermo -oxidative stability of respective blends.

The values of Tonset, DTA and Tonset, TG, DTA are smaller than those of Tonset, TG, DTG and therefore, the smallest between each other can be used as the limiting temperature, below which a specific blend presents thermo -oxidative stability in the tested conditions.

On the other hand, as the correlati on coefficients of the curves representing the Tonset, DTA and Tonset, TG, DTA as a function of the biodiesel content in the blends are very good, they indicate that they actually depend on the biodiesel contamination degree of the lubricant oil, which occ urs in a nonlinear way. It is also noticed that for values of biodiesel content in B0 up to approximately 6.5%, the oxidative thermal stability is given by Tonset, TG, DTA , when lighter oxidized products are first volatilized. However, for values of biodiesel content higher than 6.5%, the thermo -oxidative stability temperatures are given by Tonset, DTA , indicating that in these cases the oxidation in the liquid phase occurs before any volatilization.

These observations confirm the decrease in the usef ul life of lubricant oils used in diesel truck engines, when using high levels of biodiesel added to diesel, promoting by biodiesel contamination, the formation of oxidized products and sediments in the liquid phase of the lubricant oil, in a much shorter time and accelerating its oxidation process in the liquid phase at the usual temperatures to which the lubricant oils are subjected in the engine crankcase.

Acivation Energy As the thermal behavior of the lubricant and biodiesel blends are not simply due to the concentration of biodiesel in the lubricant oil (B0), the authors calculated the activation energies for the blends B2, B4 and B8 when subjected to a heating process under oxidizing conditions in air. Figure 5 shows the activation energies obtained by applying the OFW method with Doyle approximation, as a function of the degree of conversion, fo r the different percentages of biodiesel in the evaluated blends. It can be noticed that the activation energy curves up to 40% conversion, follow a same behavior, as a function of the biodiesel content. The oxidation stability is higher in the case of 2% content (B2), since much higher activation energy than in the other cases is necessary to promote the mass loss during the oxidation. It is alsoobserved that the higher is the degree of conversion in the case of B2 in air, the higher is the activation ene rgy required for its oxidation, thus promoting a higher oxidation delay in this case. This high activation energy at 2% of biodiesel contamination, indicates that there is a very intense interaction between lubricant and biodiesel in this conditions, which also explains the increase of the oxidative action of biodiesel on the lubricant

components in liquid phase. As for higher degrees of contamination by biodiesel the corresponding activation energies decrease, as shown in Figures 5 and 6, apparently this i nteraction decreases significantly with the exceeding biodiesel, what causes probably a higher volatilization at lower temperatures and consequently the decrease of the thermo - oxidative stability temperature. The activation energies of B4 and B8 blends are very similar when estimated at same conversion degrees, having the degree of conversion a very little effect on it. Since the activation energies of B4 and B8 are lower than that of B2 blends, it indicates that in these cases, as is occurring a lower i nteraction, this causes a shift of the mass loss events to lower temperatures, due to the higher present content of biodiesel which explains the lowest temperature of thermo -oxidative stability B8 case.

CONCLUSIONS  The presence of biodiesel in the lubricant causes a change of its therm al behavior, accelerating its oxidation process.

 The maximum thermo -oxidative stability temperature of the lubricant oil/ biodiesel blends has to be evaluated by Tonset,TG DTA for biodiesel contents lower than 6.5%, and by Tonset, DTA for higher contents.  In all cases the oxidation process starts in the liquid phase and the lighter oxidized fractions are released during the oxidation process as their vapor pressure increases up to the gaseous phase pressure.

 By thermal analysis the behavior of the blend TG an d DTA curves did not show changes directly proportional to the biodiesel contamination content, indicating that the chemical interactions between B0 and BD in the blends depend on the contamination degree, being the highest in B2 case.  Up to 40% degree of conversion into air, the higher is the activation energy, the higher will be the thermo -oxidative stability of the blend. TRABALHO APROVADO PELO JO URNAL OF THERMAL ANALYSIS AND CALORIMETRY C:
LIQUID PHASE OXIDATION QUANTITATIVE ANALYSIS OF BIODIESEL /DIESEL BLENDS BY DIFFERENTIAL TG AND DTA

ABSTRACT The articles and methods to analyze oxidative stability of biodiesel/diesel blends usually are based on the gaseous phase changes that occur due to vaporization and combustion of their oxidized volatile components. These blends, depending on the biodiesel content and on the storage and/or heating conditions, ma y form gums and insoluble organic particulates by oxidation in air, which may cause operating problems, decreasing diesel oil engine efficiencies. To contribute to a better analysis of these oxidized heavy component formation process, a new thermal analysi s method is presented, which quantifies them, as they are being formed in the liquid phase, during heating in oxidant atmosphere.The method was applied to commercial diesel oil and to soybean biodiesel obtained by methyl route, as well as to their blends h aving from 5 to 20 vol% of biodiesel. The authors realized that, at a same heating rate and temperature, the oxidation in liquid phase promotes a little lower mass loss in oxidant atmosphere (air) than in an inert one (N 2). Thus, by Differential Thermograv imetry (DIFTG), which consists on subtracting the TG curve obtained in inert atmosphere from the TG curve of the same sample obtained in air, the resulting DIFTG curve shows the accumulated oxidized mass as it is being formed in liquid phase, during sample components vaporization, thermal decomposition and burnout in air. Corresponding thermal effects are quantified by Differential DTA (DIFDTA) curves, subtracting respective DTA curves in N 2 from those in air. The results show that, as the biodiesel content is increased, a higher amount of its

components does not interact with diesel oil to form oxidized volatile products, but it promotes the formation of heavier ones which remain in liquid phase. This fact is confirmed by estimating the activation energies as a function of the mass loss conversion degree, which shows that, the higher is the formation rate of the liquid phase oxidized residual mass in a blend, the higher is the activation energy needed for its decomposition and the higher is its ignition temp erature, which is linearly dependent on the biodiesel volume content up to 15vol%. Keywords: Diesel /biodiesel blend, oxidation in liquid phase, ignition delay and temperature , Differential TG and DTA.

INTRODUCTION Diesel oil is a fossil fuel composed from 10 to 22 carbon atoms per hydrocarbon molecule, being a complex mixture of paraffinic, naphthenic and aromatic hydrocarbons [1]. Biodiesel is composed of alkyl esters of long chain carboxylic acids [2] and derived from organic matter of animal or vegetabl e origin biomasses, which has been used as a fuel, in addition to being renewable. Soy is one of the most important seeds in the world, with a high protein content surpassing several types of other existing oilseeds. In Brazil, it is the most used raw mate rial for biodiesel production [3].

Biodiesel, mixed with diesel oil, tends to improve the characteristics of the resulting fuel, increasing lubricity, important for low sulfur diesel oil [4]. The consumption of this mixture is viable because it results in lower CO 2 emission, high energy value, biodegradability and insignificant sulfur content in its chemical composition [2]. The 2017 current Brazilian legislation requires vehicular fleets, captive or specific, to use diesel with at least 8% in volume of bio diesel, a content that will be increased progressively up to 10 vol% in 2019 [5].

In diesel engines, the sprayed oil is compressed and mixed with air, which increases the mixture temperature promoting its spontaneous combustion (auto - ignition) [6]. Thus, any fuel oxidation interferes in its ignition delay and in the combustion process. Unstable diesel fuels can form soluble gums or insoluble organic particulates, which may occur by fuel heating during fuel system
recirculation. Both may contribute to inje ctor deposits, and to form particulates clogging fuel filters [7].

The oxidative stability of biodiesel is the main parameter to assure its quality as a fuel, which depends on its chemical composition and physicochemical properties. Depending on the numb er of existing unsaturated bonds in its molecule, there are different levels of stability to oxidation [8], which may occur in organic substrates (unsaturated fatty acids) – by hydrolysis and / or by reaction with oxygen [9]. Biodiesel can be highly reacti ve due to the presence of free radicals that generate unpaired electrons, turning the molecule highly reactive [10]. Volatile and non-volatile compounds are generated by increasing the rate of the peroxides formed by decomposition [9]. AQUI The high reactiv ity of biodiesel in oxidative ambient is due to the presence of double bonds in its structure, mainly in the presence of water, air and/or metals [8]. Often formation of hydro peroxides occurs, which, being unstable, easily react, generating by -products o f oxidation in engines, which in turn may cause problems and/or operating failures, negatively affecting the combustion performance [11]. The oxidation behavior of biodiesel has been studied extensively, mostly by analyzing what happens to the gaseous pha se due to this oxidation, by several methods, to mainly evaluate oxidation stability temperatures or oxidation times and/or oxidizing gas pressure drop at a determined temperature, among which are PetroOXY (ASTM D7545) , Pressure Differential Scanning C alorimetry, - PDSC (ASTM D5483), low P -DSC and Rancimat method - EN 14214 [12 -16]. Leonardo et al [17] reported that during thermal analyses in air of biodiesel, oxidation in liquid phase generates heavy oxidized components, a fact that does not occur wh en the same sample is analyzed in same operating conditions in nitrogen. They also reported that these high molecular heavier compounds, which initially dissolve in the liquid phase, sediment during their concentration process, as the low molecular compoun ds are released in the first step of mass loss due to vaporization, forming carbonaceous residues during their thermal decomposition at higher temperatures. The authors of the present article also noticed that when analyzing their biodiesel, diesel or th e blend samples in air, the mass loss during the evaporation step was little lower when analyzed in nitrogen. This indicates in these cases that, actually, in the presence of air, the oxidation in liquid phase forms heavier

products, which are volatilize d and/or decomposed only at higher temperatures than those of non -oxidized corresponding components in inert ambient. Thus, in the present article, to contribute to a better evaluation of these heavier oxidized components formation process, a new therm al analysis method is presented, which quantifies the oxidized mass as it is being formed in the liquid phase of those blends, when heated in oxidant atmosphere. The method is based on Differential Thermogravimetry (DIFTG), which consists on subtracting th e TG curve obtained in inert atmosphere from the TG curve obtained in air. The method was applied to TG curves, in nitrogen and air, of diesel oil, soybean biodiesel obtained by methyl route and to their blends. The resulting DIFTG curve shows the oxidize d mass increase in liquid phase as is being formed, in air ambient, followed by its decrease due to its decomposition and burnout, as the temperature is increased. Corresponding thermal effects are shown by Differential DTA (DIFDTA) subtracting respective original DTA in N 2 from that in air.

To avoid any misunderstanding of the innovative characteristics of the developed method, it must be noted that a differential thermogravimetric curve (DIFTG) curve is not equivalent to a derivative thermogravimetric (DTG) curve, as sometimes is stated incorrectly. A DIFTG curve shows the difference between two thermogravimetric (TG) curves at a same temperature or time, while a DTG curve shows the rate of mass loss at any point of a TG curve, which is, actually, the derivative of the function that represents the TG curve at any of its points, as a function of time or temperature.

It is important also to note that this liquid phase oxidation has not been quantified as it occurs so far, by any of the existent methods to evaluate oxidative stability of bio or mineral fuels. The method was applied to the studied samples, which results are evaluated and discussed in the present paper.

To see how this heavy oxidized component formation affects the activation energy of the py rolysis as a function of the conversion degree ( α) of each studied case, isoconversional methods were applied to thermogravimetric (TG) data obtained in each ambient. In this paper only the Osawa Flynn -Wall with Doyle approximation method [18] activation e nergy results are shown, because the results of the two other applied methods were very similar, as well as their respective curves as a function of the conversion degree. As will be shown, the higher obtained

activation energies in air than in nitrogen at mosphere, for a same degree of conversion, during the vaporization or thermal decomposition of the remaining liquid phase, confirmed the occurrence of the oxidation in respective liquid phases MATERIALS AND METHODS Samples preparation All specificati ons of the diesel and biodiesel soybean biodiesel commercial samples of the present study are in accordance to the requirements of the limits allowed by the Brazilian National Agency of Petroleum, Natural Gas and Biofuels (ANP) and the physicochemical stan dards according to the specifications determined by ASTM, ABNT and ISO normative entities. In addition to diesel oil (B0) and biodiesel (B100), blends of these fuels containing 5, 10,15 and 20% of biodiesel, named respectively as B5, B10, B15 and B20, we re analyzed as well. Thermal Analysis Simultaneous thermogravimetric/differential thermal analyses (TG/DTA) of all samples were performed in a TA Instruments, model - Q600, simultaneous TG/DTA/DSC equipment. Heating rates of 10 , 15 and 20ºC.min-1were used from 25 to 600ºC, using 5mg samples in open aluminum crucibles. A flow of 100 mL.min- 1was used, , of nitrogen or air as purge gases, to have, respectively, inert and oxidizing ambient during the analyses. A new aluminum crucible was always used for each a nalysis. This procedure was adapted to avoid that possible residues from an analysis could interfere into the subsequent one. Data obtained from TG/DTG/DTA curves were treated using the TA Instruments Universal Analysis software.

Differential TG and DTA cu rves For a same organic function set of substances, the higher is the organic chain and corresponding molecular weight of a substance, the lower will be its vapor pressure as a function of temperature, the higher will be its thermal stability and the higher will be its volatilization or decomposition temperature [21].

When an organic substance is oxidized without suffering any volatilization or decomposition, usually it is because more stable oxidized products are formed in liquid phase, than the correspon ding non oxidized ones. Also, when oxidation occurs with simultaneous decomposition, usually lighter products are formed, as well as heavier products in the liquid phase than the decomposed ones [21, 22]. In any case, the thermal stability of the oxidized products will depend on their respective molecular weight and structure, which will determinate respective volatilization or decomposition temperatures [22].

During thermal analyses of the analyzed samples in air, for a same sample and temperature, the ma ss losses during the evaporation or decomposition steps before auto -ignition were systematically lower than in analyses performed in nitrogen. This occurrence as previously discussed, indicates that during analyses in air, some of the biodiesel and/or dies el components were oxidized forming heavier products, which were remaining in liquid phase [23], volatilizing or decomposing only at higher temperatures than the non -oxidized corresponding components in nitrogen.

The mass of oxidized products which remain ed in liquid phase was estimated by Differential Thermogravimetry (DIFTG), subtracting the TG curve in nitrogen of a sample from its TG curve in air. As shown and discussed in the following experimental results, this procedure allows one to obtain the acc umulated oxidized mass curve in liquid phase as a function of temperature, which, in the analyzed samples, still occurs even at little higher temperatures than the corresponding auto -ignition points. The method allows obtaining the liquid phase oxidation profile of each case, which shows respective percentual mass gain during the formation of the oxidized heavy components and subsequent mass loss, during their decomposition and/or burnout in air. Differential DTA (DIFDTA) curves were also obtained by the Difference between respective DTA curves in air and nitrogen, which show respective thermal effects during the formation, decomposition and burnout of these liquid phase oxidized products.
Activation Energy and Ignition Delay

To determine the activation energy ( Eα) of the transformations in air and nitrogen, as a function of the conversion degree, the Ozawa Flynn -Wall Method with Doyle approximation kinetic isoconversional method was applied [19, 23 -25]. It is important to note that from the obtained activation en ergy (E α) values in air, it is possible to also verify the influence of the addition of biodiesel on the thermal behavior and combustion of the blends, as a function of the conversion degree ( α), as well as on the ignition delay of the studied blends, th rough equation 1 [19]: τ = f (e –Eα/RT / pb ) (eq.1) Where:

τ= ignition delay , p= pressure, T = temperature, R = Universal Constant of gases, Eα = activation energy at a conversion degree and b= kinetic coefficient . It will be seen that, the higher is the oxidized state of the liquid phase of a diesel/biodiesel blend, the higher will be the activation energy to promote its vaporization or decomposition, after which, depending on the operating conditions, ignition and combustion of the released gases may occur. From Equation 1, it can be seen that, the higher is the activation energy, the higher will also be the ignition delay, because the higher will be the vaporization or thermal decomposition temperatures of the heavier oxidized products formed in liquid phase. Thus, the higher is the formation of these products, the higher will be the interference in the performance of the diesel engines in which they will be formed. The Ozawa, Flynn and Wall method with Doyle approximation, is an isoconversional kinetic method applied to TG curve data of a same sample obtained by at least, three different βheating ratios, which estimates the value of the activation energy ( Eα) as a function of conversion degree ( α) by equation 2 : where A is the pre -exponential fac tor, R is the U niversal Constant of gases, T, is the absolute temperature , βis the heating rate and α conversion degree and g(α) is a functionof α.

At a same conversion degree Eα and g(α) are constants. Thus, from equation 2, the activation energy (Eα) can be estimated by plotting ln(β) versus 1/T values for each selected conversion degree, at different heating rates, obtaining a straight line which angular ( a) and linear ( b) coefficients are given by: The method was applied to the thermogravimetric analysis data of each of the analyzed samples, obtained using at 10, 15 and 20 ºC.min-1 heating ratios ( β), at nine different α values (f rom 0.1 to 0.9). For each conversion degree, a straight line of ln (β) as a function of 1/T was obtained, from which, the respective activation energy was calculated from its angular coefficient, applying equation 3. These determinations were done to evalu ate how the content of biodiesel addition influences on the ignition delay, since the higher is the activation energy of the first stages of mass loss, the higher will be that delay. A higher change of activation energy also indicates a higher change in the mechanism of transformations with mass loss .

RESULTS AND DISCUSSION Thermal Analysis In the following Figures are shown the TG curves obtained in inert (N 2) and oxidative (air) ambient for diesel oil (B0), biodiesel (BD) and their blends B5, B10, B15 and B20.

From Fig.1, it can be seen that at 125ºC, due to the purge gas dragging action lowering respective partial pressures in gas phase, diesel lightest components evaporate from the beginning of the analysis. For biodiesel, due to the much lower vapo r pressures of its components at same temperatures at atmospheric pressure, the mass loss due to its components evaporation just begins at that temperature. Up to 225 and 250ºC, respectively for diesel and biodiesel, from their DTA curves it can be seen th at in all analyses, there are practically only endothermic effects due to the volatilization of respective components.

Fig. 1 DTA, DTG and TG curves of row materials: B0 (diesel) and BD (biodiesel) in oxidative (air) and inert (N 2) ambient, at 10ºC.mi n-1 Up to 250ºC, B0 TG and DTG curves are similar in air and in N 2 ambient, the mass loss at a same temperature being little higher in the last case. A same behavior in mass loss occurs for BD in both ambient up to 250ºC, after which, in air, a higher m ass loss rate occurs, due to the combustion of the released gases from the decomposition of heavier carbonaceous products, as indicated by respective DTA exothermic peak in the upper part of Fig.1.

Figures 2, 3, 4 and 5 show the TG, DTG and DTA curves fo r the blends B5, B10, B15 and B20 in oxidative (air) and inert (N2) ambient. From their TG and DTG curves, in general, it can be noticed that the loss mass in air is little lower than in nitrogen ambient at a same temperature, due to the formation of h eavier oxidized components which will vaporize or decompose thermally at higher temperatures. As seen in Figure 1, this difference is more apparent for biodiesel.

B15 and B20 blends. In air, all blend DTA curves first show a significant endoth ermic peak due to vaporization of the released gases, followed by a minor exothermic peak due to the heavy components burnout, which begins by auto-ignition. In N 2 ambient, a broad endothermic peak of small intensity occurs about 250ºC, due mainly to their component evaporation and/o thermal decomposition.

Differential TG and DTA curves As previously defined, Differential Thermogravimetric curve (DIFTG) is that one obtained from the difference between two TG curves of a same sample, obtained in different thermal analysis conditions . Actually it allows one to quantify transformations that cannot be done by using only conventional thermogravimetric (TG) or derivative thermogravimetric (DTG) curves. Figure 6 shows the B0, B5, B10, B15 and B20 DIFTG curves, wh ich show the influence of the biodiesel content on the accumulated mass formation of oxidized species in the liquid phase of diesel and the studied blends. The curves are shown on respective initial sample mass basis, which were vertically shifted for a be tter comparison among each other. Figure 7 shows the B0, B5, B10, B15 and B20 DIFDTA curves , which show the influence of the biodiesel content on their respective ignition points, which increase, when the biodiesel content increases.

According to Figure 6 it can be seen that diesel oil, even when non blended with biodiesel, presents a significant accumulated formation of oxidized mass in the liquid phase (5.56%), which confirms the formation of higher molecular species, such as the cited soluble gums and insoluble organic particulates [7].

Fig. 6 DIFTG curves of B0, B5, B10, B15 and B20 samples, showing respective accumulated oxidized mass profiles in respective liquid phases during thermal analysis in air. (curves were shifted vertically for a better comparison) As biodiesel is added to diesel, in the case of B5 blend, the formation of a much lower accumulated oxidized mass in the liquid phase (1.14%) indicates that an effective interaction between diesel and biodiesel has occurred, which reduces the oxidation in liquid phase. Considering that soybean biodiesel comes with natural antioxidants [11], their action may also explain the decrease of this type of oxidized mass in liquid, which is confirmed by the fact that the auto -ignition temperature of this mixture occurs at practically the same temperature as that of diesel and according to Fig.7,B5 blend DIFDTA curve presents the lowest oxidation in the liquid phase.

Fig. 7: DIFDTA curves of B0, B5, B10, B15 and B20 samples, showing respective auto -ignition points during thermal analysis in air (curves were shifted vertically for a better comparison) B10 DIFDTA curve indicates that the increase of biodiesel concentration promotes different changes in the mechanisms of volatilization and oxidation in temp erature ranges before the occurrence of auto ignition. In B10 blend, there was a higher formation of heavier oxidized products in the liquid phase (4.95%), increasing the auto -ignition point, as shown in the DIFDTA curves of Fig.7, which maintained the liq uid phase at higher temperatures promoting its higher oxidation. This fact is even commented by other researchers who report that when petroleum derived liquid fuel is subjected to high temperatures, in the presence of air, insoluble oxidation previous cas e.

In Figure 6 the B20 DIFTG curve shows two oxidation steps, clearly indicated, by their respective exothermic peaks, which indicate that different oxidation products are being formed in each step. Very probably lighter oxidized are formed in the first s tep, which decompose at lower temperatures and heavier ones in the second one, which in turn decompose at much higher temperatures. Comparing B10 and B15 blend DIFDTA curves, there is an enlargement of the endothermic peak before the auto ignition point, indicating a higher thermal

instability and consequent higher volatilization of the products formed by interaction between diesel and biodiesel. Comparing the DIFTG curves of B15 and B20 blends, it can be seen that due to the fact that B20 contains a high er content of biodiesel, the formation of the oxidized products in the liquid phase occurs in two stages. In the first one, there is a small peak at 178 °C generating a temporary maximum of 1.78% accumulated oxidized mass, after which it decreases, indicat ing that some of the lighter formed products volatilize. Between 200 and 205°C begins a second oxidation stage in the liquid phase, with a maximum formation rate at 228°C, with an accumulated oxidized mass of 2.48%.

Table 1: B0, B5, B10, B15 and B20 liqu id phase accumulated oxidized masses Sample Accumulated oxidized mass in liquid phase / % Temperature of maximum formation / º C Figure 8 shows how the ignition temperatu re and the temperature of maximum released heat flux during combustion of the evolved gases are correlated with the biodiesel content in the blend. It is important to note that the up to 15 vol% of biodiesel these temperatures increase linearly with BD c ontent, after which their respective increasing rate decreases.

The above data indicate that when heated in air, independently of the evolution of a significant mass of gases by vaporization or by cracking of the hevier componentsof the blends, oxidized mass is formed in the liquid phase of the diesel/biodiesel blends, part of which remains as a carbonaceous residue. This residual heavier products may cause diesel engine cycle problems such as, filter clogging, hampering the engine burning process [8] and requiring replacement of engine damaged parts at a higher frequency than when the fuel is only diesel.

In the case of Biodiesel in Figure 10, besides that at atmospheric pressure it is more stable than diesel oil and for this reason needs higher activation energies for its volatilizat ion and thermal decomposition, as it has oxygen in its composition, which facilitates its oxidation in any ambient, it presents a lower change of the activation energy as a function of conversion degree in air. In Figure 10, although in N 2, for lower co nversion degrees the activation energies for biodiesel are lower than in air because there is no oxidation in liquid phase, for the higher conversion degrees the activation energies are higher than in air, because heavier components are progressively dec omposed only by thermal action.
Figures 11 to 14 show the activation energy curves of the studied B5, B10, B15 and B20 blends. Different behavior occurs in an inert (N 2) or oxidant ambient (air).

In this case, it is important to note that there is a slight and almost same increase of Eα in both ambient as conversion increases, indicating a significant interaction between the row material such as diesel (B0) and biodiesel (BD). The activation energy increases almost linearly with the conversion degree, due to the thermal decomposition of the increasing heavier components as seen in Figures 2 and 6, which occurs in a practically same way, also indicating a very good compatibility and miscibility of both fuels in this blend.

Fig.12 shows B10 blend activation energy curves. This time it can be noticed that there is a significant difference of Eα for the two kinds of ambient, showing that the major content of biodiesel forms more oxidized products in liquid phase than in B5 case,. This can be probably due to the higher biodiesel content interacting with those of diesel, causing a higher oxidizing effect in liquid phase, with a progressive formation of more oxidized and heavier products in liquid phase, as seen in Figure 6. These oxidation products need higher temperatures for their thermal decomposition and consequently, higher activation energies at the new higher temperatures as seen in Figure 11. In B10 case, it must be reminded that a higher oxidation occurs in liquid phase in air ambient, due to also air oxidation action, causing h igher activation energies of thermal decomposition in air than in N2, in all conversion degrees, as noted in Fig 12.
